title: Keira Knightley goes make-up free and carries newborn baby Delilah
text:
She recently joked she'd barely had time to brush her own hair since her second daughter was born last month.

And Keira Knightley enjoyed some quality time with her newborn baby girl, Delilah, and her mother, playwright Sharman Macdonald, 68, as they headed out for a bite to eat at the Towpath Café in Haggerston, east London, on Monday.

The actress, 34, went make-up free for her family day, accessorising with a pair of trendy circular spectacles as she stepped out with her daughter strapped close to her chest in a Baby Bjorn carrier.

Family values: Keira Knightley and her newborn baby girl, Delilah, headed out for lunch with her mother, Sharman Macdonald, 68, at the Towpath Café in east London on Monday

The Imitation Game star wrapped up against the chilly autumnal weather in a grey wool coat, which she teamed with a checked button-down dress.

The mother-of-two kept comfortable in a pair of black lace-up boots and wore her brunette hair in loose waves.

Keira kept Delilah close as the group headed to lunch, with only the newborn's lilac socks and white babygrow visible.

The talented actress and her husband of six years, former Klaxons rocker James Righton, 36, confirmed the arrival of their second child last month when they were pictured out in London with their baby daughter.

Doting mother: The actress, 34, went make-up free for her family day out, accessorising with a pair of trendy circular spectacles as she stepped out with her daughter strapped close

Lunch date: The Imitation Game star wrapped up against the chilly autumnal weather in a grey wool coat, which she teamed with a checked button-down dress

The couple are also proud parents to daughter Edie, four.

Keira revealed she was pregnant for a second time in May when she debuted her bump at the Chanel J12 party in Paris, France.

The screen star and her musician husband have been together since early 2011, and married in May 2013 in an intimate ceremony in the South of France.

Last week, Keira opened up about becoming a parent once again in her first interview since giving birth, joking she'd barely had time to brush her hair since little Delilah came into the world.

Speaking to journalist Louise Minchin on BBC Breakfast on Friday morning, she said: 'This is the third time since I've given birth that my hair has been brushed and I didn't brush it.

New mummy: The mother-of-two kept comfortable in a pair of black lace-up boots and wore her brunette hair in loose waves

So sweet: Keira kept Delilah close as the group headed to lunch, with only the newborn's lilac socks and white babygrow visible

'Lovely Luke who was my hairdresser today, he brushed it. I was in my pyjamas when they got there and this is somebody else's dress.

'So this is all smoke and mirrors today, which I'm super happy about. I've just sort of been led here.'

When asked what her advice for 'normal mothers' is, the British actress replied: 'You should still be in your pyjamas.

'And don't brush your hair and let the house be a complete mess and only see people who are going to bring you food.'

In January, Keira spoke of the challenges surrounding motherhood and juggling her acting career with caring for her daughter.

Mother-of-two: Keira recently joked she'd barely had time to brush her own hair since her second daughter was born last month

She told Balance magazine: 'I don't think we give women enough credit for the physical and emotional marathon they go through when becoming a mother.

'I come from a place of amazing privilege. I have an incredible support system; I’ve been unbelievably lucky in my career; I can afford good childcare, and yet I still find it really f***ing difficult.'

She added: 'It's OK to say that. It doesn’t mean I don't love my kid, it's just me admitting that the sleep deprivation, the hormonal changes, the shift in relationship with my partner, are all things that make me feel as if I’m failing on a daily basis.

'I have to remind myself that I haven't failed, I'm just doing what I can do, but it’s not easy.'
